fields.value: Behavioral Tracking Survey (FSW & High risk MSM)- II - 2012 (By Alliance)

dsDescriptionValue.value: The objectives of the Behavioural Tracking Survey (BTS) were (1) To measure the major outcomes and impacts of the interventions funded by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (BMGF) under the Avahan India AIDS Initiative by collecting behavioral trend data in populations targeted by the interventions. (2) To understand the relationship between community mobilization and service indicator outcomes such as promotion of condom use, reduction in violence and improved service utilization. This survey was conducted in the five districts (Khammam, Warangal, Kurnool, Medak and Ananthapur) of Andhra Pradesh for FSW population, while it covered only three districts (Khammam, Kurnool and Ananthapur) for High risk MSM population.

keywordValue.value: Advocacy, Behavioral tracking surveys with FSWs, Behavioral tracking surveys with MSM, Community mobilization, Community mobilization monitoring research (Avahan-CMMR), FSW, High risk MSM, HIV, Sexual behavior; INSTITUTION: HIV/AIDS Alliance;  STRATEGIC AREAS: FSWs, High risk MSM

publicationCitation.value: Saggurti N, Mishra RM, Proddutoor L, Tucker S, Kovvali D, Prabhakar P, Wheeler T. Community collectivization and its association with selected outcomes among female sex workers and high-risk men who have sex with men/transgenders in Andhra Pradesh, India. AIDS Care: Link

Saggurti N, Mishra RM, Proddutoor L, Tucker S, Kovvali D, Prabhakar P, Wheeler T. Community collectivization and its association with selected outcomes among female sex workers and high-risk men who have sex with men/transgenders in Andhra Pradesh, India. AIDS Care: Link
India HIV/AIDS Alliance, Behavioral Tracking System in Andhra Pradesh, Round II Report- 2012, Hyderabad, India

value: India HIV/AIDS Alliance, 2012. Behavioral Tracking System in Andhra Pradesh, Round II Report, Hyderabad, India
FSWs and High risk MSM Population

fields.value: Behavioral Tracking Survey (BTS) round 2, was conducted in 5 districts ( Khammam,  Warangal, Krnuool,  Medak,  Ananthpur) of Andhra Pradesh to monitor key components of the Avahan program: community mobilization, safe sex behavior, and STI treatment-seeking behavior. Conventional cluster sampling and Time location cluster sampling methods were used to  select the respondents from different clusters in districts. With in different clusters a total of 3149 samples were collected in AP.  A sample of 1973 FSWs were selected from Khammam, Warangal, Kurnool, Medak and Ananthapur districts of AP. While a total of 1176 High risk MSMs sample were selected from Khammam, Kurnool and Ananthapur districts of AP. The eligible Female Sex Workers (FSW) taken in the study were females aged 18 years or older, either brothel or street or lodge or home based, who sold sex in exchange for cash at least once in the past one month. Whereas Men who have Sex with other Men (High risk MSM) were taken from men aged 18 years or older, who had sex (oral/manual/anal) with other men at least once in the past one month.
